thread.title: Big Review TV beefs up revenue
thread.title_full: Big Review TV beefs up revenue | Business Spectator

author: Jennifer Foreshew
title: Big Review TV beefs up revenue
text:
Australian start-up Big Review TV has more than 11,000 members in its pipeline as it looks to grow content for the business-to-consumer market.
The Sydney-based company shoots and packages online video reviews for small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) clients, including restaurants, salons and hotels.
The popular video market has seen Facebook boast about 4 billion video views per day in April, up from 3 billion in January and one billion in September last year.
ASX-listed Big Un Limited, the parent company of Big Review TV, has announced it has exceeded its revenue projections for the September quarter.
In Q3 2015, the company generated $406,582 in cash receipts, ahead of its $350,000 guidance and a 75 per cent lift on Q2 2015. It also achieved another significant milestone, reaching more than 10,000 members during the September quarter. This growth represents acceleration of more than 100 per cent since January 2015.
The company is on track to exceed $1 million in annual sales.
Big Review TV founder Brandon Evertz, who started the company as a teenager three years ago, said the partnership with CDM Direct Communication Services and other sales initiatives had facilitated the acceleration of revenue and member growth.
“We started on 15 sales staff now we have grown to 55 sales staff so that (CDM) has really been the rocket fuel in helping us get the numbers that we need,’’ he told The Australian. “We still want to continue to build that sales number by the end of December up to, hopefully, around 100 sales reps.’’
Earlier this year, the company announced it had successfully raised $3 million via an oversubscribed capital raising, with strong interest from existing and new investors.
The cost to produce a promotional video starts at $399, with a monthly subscription from $7.50. The service is free for the public.
The company’s growing member base forms a strong part of its revenue base, with an increasing amount of members who sign up to Big Review TV’s online video content offering, converting to recurring subscription-based membership terms.
“We are really starting to have a strong footprint overseas in building that content base,’’ the 21-year-old said.
The company’s initial target markets are Australia, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, the United States and Singapore.
“In member growth, I would probably say 70 to 80 per cent would be Australia and then 10 per cent in the US and the UK.’’
Sales are expected to accelerate during the December quarter based on a robust sales pipeline and material uplift in recurring revenues.
Mr Evertz, who is Big Un Limited executive director, said the plan was to add to the business-to-business model with a business-to-consumer focus.
“We are producing that content for the businesses but the next sort of step is to really start building a great, engaging show content base for consumers.’’
He said the main priority would be to continue to build member growth, with the company potentially based in the US in the future.
“The US is ideally where we would like to be but, regardless, we still have operations in the US anyway so we will continue to build up that.’’
